dc:description:
The *MED27* gene is located on chromosome 9 at 9q34.13 and encodes a subunit of the Mediator multiprotein complex, which is involved in transcriptional regulation (PMID 9989412). *MED27* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive neurodevelopmental disorder with spasticity, cataracts, and cerebellar hypoplasia in 2021 (Meng et al., PMID: 33443317). Sixteen variants (11 missense, 1 in-frame indel, 3 frameshift and 1 splicing) that have been reported in 30 probands in two publications (PMIDs: 33443317, 37517035) are included in this curation. Variants in this gene segregated with disease in families with multiple affected family members. The mechanism of pathogenicity is reported to be loss of function (PMID: 16582438). ​

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by experimental evidence (biochemical, protein interactions and animal models) (PMIDs: 9989412, 37516429, 16582438, 36305825, 30091705, 31613003). Other genes that code for mediator complex subunits (*MED12*, *MED13*, *MED13L*, *MED17*, *MED25* and *CDK8*) are definitively or strongly associated with conditions involving developmental, language and motor delay, intellectual disability, seizures, cataracts and microcephaly. A knockout zebrafish model showed a reduction in head size and abnormal neurological development (PMID 16582438). Early lethality was observed in *MED27* gene knockouts in mouse, fruit fly and chicken (PMIDs: 36305825, 30091705, 31613003). While these latter three models do not necessarily recapitulate the disease phenotype, the observation that no reported human cases have been homozygous or compound heterozygous for loss-of-function variants suggests that complete loss of function of MED27 may be embryonically lethal. 

In summary, there is strong evidence to support the relationship between *MED27* and autosomal recessive neurodevelopmental disorder with spasticity, cataracts, and cerebellar hypoplasia. Three years must elapse from the first proposal of the assertion to reach a definitive classification without any valid contradictory evidence. We will re-evaluate this gene-disease relationship at that time to determine if an upgraded classification of definitive is warranted. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Syndromic Disorders GCEP on the meeting date 12/15/2023 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description:
-1: Model does not recapitulate all phenotypes associated with this condition.
-0.5: Rescue is not a human allele, but a zebrafish allele

As an experimental system, the authors chose the developing zebrafish retina, since it represents one of the best-studied units of the CNS and allows detection of developmental defects at high resolution. Mutant zebrafish showed a reduction in head size when compared to wild-type and abnormal neurological development, phenotypes of humans with the condition.
evidence.rdfs:label: MED27 Knockout Zebrafish Model

evidence.dc:description: Chicken model does not recapitulate the disease phenotype: lethality. However, no human cases that are homozygous or compound heterozygous for loss-of-function variants have been reported, suggesting that complete loss of function may be embryonically lethal.
Death before adulthood was seen in 16% of cases
evidence.rdfs:label: MED27 Knockout Chicken Model

evidence.dc:description: Drosophila model does not recapitulate the disease phenotype. Deletion of Med27 is pupal lethal. However, no human cases that are homozygous or compound heterozygous for loss-of-function variants have been reported, suggesting that complete loss of function may be embryonically lethal.
Death before adulthood was seen in 16% of cases
evidence.rdfs:label: MED27 Knockout Drosophila Model

evidence.dc:description: Mouse model does not recapitulate the disease phenotype: pre-weaning lethality. However, no human cases that are homozygous or compound heterozygous for loss-of-function variants have been reported, suggesting that complete loss of function may be embryonically lethal.
Death before adulthood was seen in 16% of cases
evidence.rdfs:label: MED27 Knockout Mouse Model

evidence.dc:description: There are ≥3 proteins with the same function that are involved in the same/similar disease

The mediator complex is made up of a head, middle, tail and CDK-kinase module. MED12, MED13, MED13L and CDK8 make up the CDK-kinase module. MED17 is a subunit of the head module. MED25 and MED27 make up subunits of the tail module.
evidence.rdfs:label: MED27 is a subunit of the mediator complex

evidence.dc:description: There are ≥3 proteins with the same function that are involved in the same/similar disease

MED27 was isolated and characterized in Ryu et al., PMID 9989412 as part of the mediator complex, necessary for transcriptional activation, after which the other mediator complex components have been identified and described.

The mediator complex is made up of a head, middle, tail and CDK-kinase module. MED12, MED13, MED13L and CDK8 make up the CDK-kinase module. MED17 is a subunit of the head module. MED25 and MED27 make up subunits of the tail module.

MED12 is 'definitively' associated with intellectual disability syndrome (ClinGen). MED13 is 'definitively' associated with complex neurodevelopmental disorder (including global developmental, language and motor delay and intellectual disability) (ClinGen). MED13L is 'definitively' associated with syndromic intellectual disability (including global developmental, language and motor delay and seizures) (ClinGen). MED17 is associated with infantile cerebral and cerebellar atrophy with postnatal progressive microcephaly with classifications of 'strong' (GenCC: G2P, Invitae) and 'supportive' (GenCC: Orphanet). MED25 is associated with congenital cataract-microcephaly-nevus flammeus simplex-severe intellectual disability syndrome with classifications of 'definitive' (GenCC: G2P), and 'moderate' (GenCC: Ambry). CDK8 is associated with intellectual developmental disorder with hypotonia and behavioral abnormalities with classifications of 'strong' (Invitae) and 'moderate' (Ambry)
evidence.rdfs:label: MED27 interacts with proteins involved in similar disease
